case_vignette: A previously healthy 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of nervousness and difficulty sleeping over the past 4 weeks. She has difficulty falling asleep at night because she cannot stop worrying about her relationship and her future. Three months ago, her new boyfriend moved in with her. Before this relationship, she had been single for 13 years. She reports that her boyfriend does not keep things in order in the way she was used to. Sometimes, he puts his dirty dishes in the kitchen sink instead of putting them in the dishwasher directly. He refuses to add any groceries to the shopping list when they are used up. He has also suggested several times that they have dinner at a restaurant instead of eating at home, which enrages her because she likes to plan each dinner of the week and buy the required groceries beforehand. The patient says that she really loves her boyfriend but that she will never be able to tolerate his “flaws.” Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is cooperative but appears distressed. Her affect has little intensity or range.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been feeling really nervous and I'm having trouble sleeping for the past 4 weeks.
Is this anxiety accompanied by rapid heartbeat or shortness of breath?
No, I haven't mentioned experiencing a rapid heartbeat or shortness of breath.
Have you noticed any changes in appetite or weight loss during this time?
I haven't mentioned anything about changes in my appetite or weight loss.
Do you have a history of depression or anxiety disorders?
Before this, I was previously healthy and didn't mention a history of depression or anxiety disorders.
Have you been under significant stress lately, such as a new job, relationship, or major life change?
Yes, my new boyfriend moved in with me three months ago, and that has been stressful for me.
Final Diagnosis: Adjustment Disorder with Anxiety.

The patient denies experiencing a rapid heartbeat or shortness of breath, as well as any changes in appetite or weight loss. The patient reports no history of depression or anxiety disorders but does mention that their new boyfriend moved in with them three months ago, causing stress.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: Generalized anxiety disorder. The patient's symptoms of excessive worry and difficulty sleeping due to relationship concerns and her boyfriend's habits are consistent with this diagnosis. Obsessive-compulsive personality disorder may also be considered, but the presence of excessive worries and anxiety about multiple aspects of her life points more towards generalized anxiety disorder. Obsessive-compulsive disorder is characterized by recurrent and intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions) that the person feels driven to perform. Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a lack of desire for social relationships or social interaction.
